awd_titl_txt: Collaborative research:  Calibration of deep-sea coral paleoproxies for nutrients, carbonate ion, and temperature
awd_abstract_narration:
The ocean exchanges heat, moisture, and carbon dioxide with the atmosphere and plays a large role in earth's climate, both in the past and present day. This project seeks to understand and quantify physical and chemical properties of the deep ocean in the past by developing geochemical tools to analyze trace elements in the fossil skeletons of deep-sea corals. This approach has the potential to reveal how critical regions of the deep ocean changed in nutrient and carbon content, as well as temperature, over the last glacial cycle, in ways that have not been possible previously. The project will be carried out in collaboration with Spanish colleagues in Barcelona, who are experts in the maintenance of deep-sea corals in aquarium culture. The research team will grow living cultures of the solitary coral species Desmophyllum dianthus over a period of months to years, while carefully controlling the chemical composition and temperature of the seawater in which they grow. By calibrating the composition of the calcium carbonate skeletons of these organisms relative to tightly controlled seawater properties in the laboratory and in the modern ocean, the researchers will develop quantitative relationships that enable analysis of well-dated fossil corals and inference of the properties of the seawater in which the ancient corals grew. Such fossils can be collected from the sea bottom and dated. Large collections have been archived from the waters around New Zealand, a critical region for ocean-atmosphere interactions. Knowing the seawater properties from archived and new seawater measurements in this region will allow the principal investigators to test the conclusions found in the lab against relationships seen in corals growing in the natural ocean. The goal is to develop tools to establish the degree to which atmospheric carbon dioxide was controlled over the last glacial cycle by ocean productivity and gas exchange. The project will support a PhD student and facilitate international exchange in addition to training K-12 teachers. Overall, the project contributes to technical expertise development in the US and will allow an improved understanding of how our changing ocean affects global climate.

In this collaborative project, a chemical paleoceanographer and a marine microgeochemistry expert will collaborate to carry out an extensive laboratory experiment that will take advantage of a large (>150 individuals) collection of living D. dianthus, currently in culture at the Institut de Ciencies del Mar-Barcelona under automatically-controlled seawater chemistry and temperature. Laser ablation ICP-MS micro-geochemical techniques will be used to calibrate precisely the skeletal P/Ca (nutrient), Ba/Ca ("nutrient-type"), U/Ca (carbonate ion) and Mg/Li (temperature) proxies, and to investigate their secondary sensitivities to pH, feeding rate, calcification rate, and temperature. A previously unexploited collection of live-collected (dredged) D. dianthus corals, harvested over a broad range of hydrographically well-characterized subtropical and subantarctic waters around New Zealand, will also be analyzed for these proxies. The project will thus result in complementary laboratory and field-based calibrations of these new geochemical paleo-proxies, that can then be used in future efforts to analyze precisely dated collections of fossil corals. The unique set of samples from ongoing culture experiments and open-ocean archives, combined with the capabilities of a state-of-the-art laser ablation ICP-MS system and precision micro-milling techniques, will reduce significantly the uncertainties in calibrations for an important set of D. dianthus-based paleoproxies. This work will serve as a cornerstone for future coral paleo-reconstruction studies.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Deep-sea corals of the species Desmophyllum dianthus are a new tool in paleoceanography with several promising characteristics. This globally distributed coral species can be found in a wide depth range, as shallow as 4 m and as deep as 2500 m. Furthermore, D. dianthus features a broad thermal tolerance of 2-14?C. The relatively large size of their skeletons (5-25 cm) allows multiple proxies to be applied within the same individual specimen. The skeletons can be dated using U-Th radiochronometry, providing a single precise calendar age that is unaffected by bioturbation. Slow growth rates of the coral skeleton (~1 mm/year) and long lifespans allow the possibility to quantifying sub-decadal ocean variability over a range of depths during century-long time slices over the last glacial cycle. In addition, growth axes within the skeleton are relatively easy to follow, providing the potential for sub-annual resolution of intermediate and deep-water variability. The Element/Calcium ratios of the aragonite skeleton represent potential archives for paleo-reconstruction of several ocean properties.

Applications of D. dianthus as archives of past climates have been limited because of relatively large uncertainties in their calibrations, combined with significant chemical heterogeneity in their skeletal composition. We refined the calibration of P/Ca, Ba/Ca, U/Ca, and Li/Mg proxies for seawater phosphate, barium, carbonate ion concentration, and temperature, respectively. We addressed the aforementioned issues by analyzing corals that were cultured by our colleagues at the ICM, Spain, under systematically varied seawater conditions (phosphate, barium, temperature, pH, feeding frequency, and enriched Pb as isotope marker) over a two-year period. A calcein treatment was applied to mark the skeletal material with fluorescent dye at each change in chemistry (see attached figure). These cultured corals, used for proxy-calibration, were supplemented by live-collected corals near New Zealand.

In this collaborative project (collaboration between the Lamont-Doherty Earth Observatory of Columbia University and Rutgers University), new methods were developed and existing approaches refined for (1) cleaning of coral skeletons, epoxy-mounting, sectioning, polishing, and fabricating slide-mounted thin sections for subsequent imaging and chemical analysis; (2) confocal microscopic identification of calcein-stained growth lines that mark amendment steps during life-culturing at the ICM; (3) elemental mapping of septal thin sections with ~10 ?m resolution, using laser ablation ICP-MS (LA-ICP-MS) techniques, and (4) standardization for LA-ICP-MS using carbonate and NIST glass standards in comparison with solution phase ICP-MS. Method development for elemental mapping and standardization as well as proxy-calibration work will continue at Rutgers University.

The newly developed strategies for sectioning the corals provide the unique opportunity to observe details of skeletal growth periods on the time scale of months, relative to the overall bulk morphology of the skeleton. The pattern of skeletal growth, visualized through the orientation of the calcein stain lines (6?9 month intervals), reveals that it is more complex, asymmetric, and temporally variable than initially envisioned. This finding will inform a refined model of skeletal growth and provides domains representing a range of calcification rates that can be exploited to investigate the impact of calcification rate on element/Ca ratios.

Our method refinement for LA-ICP-MS analysis allows to geochemically resolve ~6 month increments in this slowly growing (1-2 mm/year) organisms using calcein and Pb isotope labeling, and to assess the variability introduced by biological factors such as feeding frequency and extension rate. Furthermore, regions in the skeleton that are optimal for paleoproxy signals can now be identified and compositional variability constrained using LA-ICPMS mapping

This research will ultimately lead to the quantitative use of fossil corals for reconstructing aspects of nutrient, carbonate system, and temperature distributions in the past ocean, all important variables in understanding the ocean?s role in climate change over Earth?s history. The results of this study will allow a better understanding of the variability of the ocean system and thus its effects on past and future climate change, with implications for human society and its success into the future.

Results from this work have been presented at multiple national and international conferences (AGU 2019, Goldschmidt 2019, ICP 13, 2019, AGU 2020), and manuscripts are prepared for publication in peer-reviewed journals.
